awd_titl_txt: RUI: Electron Transfer and Inhibition of Dihydromethanopterin Reductase
awd_abstract_narration:
Methane-generating microorganisms (methanogens) synthesize methane as both an alternative energy source and a greenhouse gas.  In addition to their environmental impacts, these organisms are medically important because methanogens in the human gut have been correlated with obesity.  Research in the principal investigator's laboratory focuses on the discovery of proteins needed for microbial methane generation and the development of chemical inhibitors that may decrease methanogen contributions to greenhouse gases and obesity in the future.  The research is conducted by high school students, undergraduates, and graduate students at California State University at Fullerton, a primary undergraduate institution and Hispanic-serving university.  This research contributes to the reduction of biological methane production and to the development of the next generation of scientific researchers in the United States.

With this award, the Chemistry of Life Processes Program in the Chemistry Division is funding research by Professor Madeline Rasche at California State University-Fullerton to understand and chemically inhibit dihydromethanopterin reductase.  Tetrahydromethanopterin (H4MPT) is an unusual folate-like cofactor required for the microbial synthesis of methane as an energy source and greenhouse gas.  The flavoprotein dihydromethanopterin reductase (Dmr) catalyzes the final step in the biosynthesis of H4MPT, and this enzyme is a potential target for chemical inhibitors designed to mitigate biological methane production.  Based on the X-ray crystal structure of dihydromethanopterin reductase B (DmrB) from Burkholderia xenovorans, a ping-pong mechanism for electron transfer has been proposed.  The goal of this NSF-funded research is to test structure-based hypotheses about the mechanism of electron transfer in the bacterial protein (DmrB) and in a homolog of dihydromethanopterin reductase (DmrX) from a true methane-producing microorganism.  The research is conducted by an integrated network of high school students, undergraduates, and graduate students at California State University at Fullerton, a primarily undergraduate institution and Hispanic-serving university. This research contributes to the development of chemical inhibitors of methane as a greenhouse gas and to the education of the next generation of chemistry researchers in the United States.

por.por_cntn:
Methanogenic microorganisms synthesize methane as a beneficial clean-burning fuel, and yet methane is also a greenhouse gas associated with climate change. When found in the human digestive tract, these organisms also correlate with human obesity.  Biological methane production requires the chemical tetrahydromethanopterin (H4MPT). Therefore, the proteins or enzymes needed for H4MPT synthesis have been identified as targets for additives or drugs that may block the activity of methane-producing microorganisms in human intestines and the environment.  One potential target for inhibition is the last enzyme of H4MPT biosynthesis, dihydromethanopterin reductase (Dmr).  Understanding the function and mechanism of Dmr will facilitate the discovery of future inhibitors of methane-producing microorganisms.

The overall goal of the research was to test structure-based hypotheses about the mechanism of electron transfer in dihydromethanopterin reductase B (DmrB) and in its homolog from methane-producing microorganisms (DmrX).  We first tested the proposed “ping-pong” mechanism of electron transfer and found that, indeed, electrons from NADH could be transferred to flavin mononucleotide (FMN) and then to the internal FMN of DmrB.  We also found that an iron-containing protein called ferredoxin could be used to add electrons to the enzyme.  Furthermore, these two methods reduced a second H4MPT synthesis enzyme (Orf19) (Pang et al., manuscript in preparation). 

The three-dimensional structure of Orf19 was determined by X-ray crystallography in collaboration with University of California, Los Angeles scientists (Saleh et al., manuscript in preparation.)  Additionally, a computational model of DmrX was created to examine potential pathways of electron flow.  Based on the model, within a single subunit, the two metal centers that contain iron and sulfur (4Fe-4S centers) were too far away to allow electron transfer to the FMN molecule within the enzyme active site.  Instead, it is proposed that the active site is formed at the interface of two molecules of DmrX and that electrons from the 4Fe-4S clusters of one subunit may donate electrons to the FMN in the other subunit.    

In some bacteria, dihydromethanopterin reductase (DmrA) is similar in structure to dihydrofolate reductase (Dfr), one of the main protein targets for anti-cancer chemotherapy drugs.  However, in publicly available protein databases, there was confusion about close relatives of DmrA that may be mistakenly labeled as diacylglycerol kinases.  To clarify the issue, we showed that proteins with sequence similarity as low as 69% all exhibited Dmr activity, and were therefore were likely to be dihydromethanopterin reductases instead of diacylglycerol kinases (Burton et al., 2018).

In terms of educational impact, the grant supported the research projects of seven Master’s students, over 30 undergraduate thesis researchers, 20 students in the course “Advances in Biotechnology Laboratory”, and about 12 sections of biotechnology students in their classroom at Dana Hills High School.  Among the accomplishments of these students were creating 20 site-directed variants of DmrB, advancing progress in developing a new DmrB assay, and producing preliminary crystals of the DmrA and another H4MPT biosynthesis drug target. Students presented 14 posters and two oral presentations at regional and state-wide conferences.  One of the high school students joined the laboratory of the principal investigator.  With his extensive experience, he was able to manage the laboratory inventory and train new undergraduate and graduate students.          

As part of a cross-disciplinary educational collaboration with Dr. Nina Robson of the Mechanical Engineering Department, a new lower division course was developed to engage freshmen and sophomores in cross-disciplinary research.  In the course “Early Research Experiences in Biomedical and Bioengineering” (EGGN 122), students learned fundamental principles of mechanical engineering and protein biochemistry and worked on team projects, including the design of folded DNA nanostructures (DNA origami) intended to deliver chemotherapeutic drugs to cancer cells (Robson et al., manuscript accepted).  Partly funded by the California State University Program for Education and Research in Biotechnology (CSUPERB), two mechanical engineering students, two biology students, a biochemist, an English major, and a community college intern continued research in a summer internship.  The students designed the DNA nanostructure and began to implement its assembly.  The students (including two sophomores and a community college student) presented two posters at the state-wide 2019 CSUPERB Symposium and were invited to give a “lightning talk” in front of the 400-person audience. Two students won a local oral presentation competition, and they will represent our university at the state competition in April 2019.  The students also submitted a manuscript to the college’s journal of undergraduate research Dimensions.      

In summary, the NSF research grant has contributed to deepening our understanding of biological methane production and enzymes that are targets for decreasing greenhouse gases and possibly obesity. The funding has contributed to the research education of graduate and undergraduate students at a Hispanic-serving institution as well as biotechnology students at Dana Hills High School, thus contributing to the development of the scientific workforce of the future.
